elements.content: A new 2-pyridyl-1,2,3-triazole (pytri) ligand, TPA-pytri, substituted with a triphenylamine (TPA) donor group on the 5 position of the pyridyl unit was synthesized and characterized. Dichloroplatinum­(II), bis­(phenylacetylide)­platinum­(II), bromotricarbonylrhenium­(I), and bis­(bipyridyl)­ruthenium­(II) complexes of this ligand were synthesized and compared to complexes of pytri ligands without the TPA substituent. The complexes of unsubstituted pytri ligands show metal-to-ligand charge-transfer (MLCT) absorption bands involving the pytri ligand in the near-UV region. These transitions are complemented by intraligand charge-transfer (ILCT) bands in the TPA-pytri complexes, resulting in greatly improved visible absorption (λmax = 421 nm and ϵ = 19800 M–1 cm–1 for [Pt­(TPA-pytri)­Cl2]). The resonance Raman enhancement patterns allow for assignment of these absorption bands. The [Re­(TPA-pytri)­(CO)3Br] and [Pt­(TPA-pytri)­(CCPh)2] complexes were examined with time-resolved infrared spectroscopy. Shifts in the CC and CO stretching bands revealed that the complexes form states with increased electron density about their metal centers. [Pt­(TPA-pytri)­Cl2] is unusual in that it is emissive despite the presence of deactivating d–d states, which prevents emission from the unsubstituted pytri complex.

elements.content:
Electron-donor-substituted pyridyltriazole ligands yield strongly colored metal complexes with photophysics dominated by the intraligand charge-transfer state.

Introduction

The design of molecules for light-harvesting applications requires the balancing of many electronic properties. Platinum­(II) and ruthenium­(II) complexes have been studied as dyes for dye-sensitized solar cells and hydrogen production catalysts. Rhenium­(I) complexes have been used in organic light-emitting diodes, as bioimaging agents and as CO2 reduction catalysts. Strong absorption of visible light is often an important goal in designing molecules for these applications, and investigations including steady state and time-resolved vibrational spectroscopy are useful tools in elucidation of the nature and interplay between excited states.
elements.clean_text:
Electron-donor-substituted pyridyltriazole ligands yield strongly colored metal complexes with photophysics dominated by the intraligand charge-transfer state.

Introduction

The design of molecules for light-harvesting applications requires the balancing of many electronic properties. Platinum(II) and ruthenium(II) complexes have been studied as dyes for dye-sensitized solar cells and hydrogen production catalysts. Rhenium(I) complexes have been used in organic light-emitting diodes, as bioimaging agents and as CO2 reduction catalysts. Strong absorption of visible light is often an important goal in designing molecules for these applications, and investigations including steady state and time-resolved vibrational spectroscopy are useful tools in elucidation of the nature and interplay between excited states.

elements.content: Photoexcitation of these complexes generally involves metal-to-ligand charge-transfer (MLCT)-type transitions, which have moderate intensity and may not extend into the visible region. For instance, [Ru­(phen)3]2+ has an MLCT band at 445 nm (ϵ = 17000 M–1 cm–1) in acetonitrile. Changing the energies of the metal-based dπ and diimine-based π* orbitals, which act as the electron donor and acceptor in MLCT transitions, is one way of tuning the absorption bands of such complexes. It is also possible to append electron-accepting groups such as arylboranes to increase the conjugation length of the molecule and increase the extinction coefficient of the MLCT band.
elements.clean_text: Photoexcitation of these complexes generally involves metal-to-ligand charge-transfer (MLCT)-type transitions, which have moderate intensity and may not extend into the visible region. For instance, [Ru(phen)3]2+ has an MLCT band at 445 nm (ϵ = 17000 M-1 cm-1) in acetonitrile. Changing the energies of the metal-based dπ and diimine-based π* orbitals, which act as the electron donor and acceptor in MLCT transitions, is one way of tuning the absorption bands of such complexes. It is also possible to append electron-accepting groups such as arylboranes to increase the conjugation length of the molecule and increase the extinction coefficient of the MLCT band.

elements.content: Appending organic chromophores to an inorganic complex results in enhanced absorption and interesting excited-state properties. For example, the covalent linking of coumarin chromophores to [Ru­(phen)3]2+ complexes results in increased absorption in the UV region, but emission from the [Ru­(phen)3]2+ 3MLCT state is maintained regardless of the excitation wavelength. Attachment of other chromophores such as pyrene or 4-piperidinyl-1,8-naphthalimide to ruthenium­(II) or rhenium­(I) complexes gives enhanced absorption as well as increased excited-state lifetimes due to the triplet reservoir effect. The absorption spectra of the complexes appear essentially as a combination of the spectra of the parent chromophore and complex.

The absorption spectra of the complexes appear essentially as a combination of the spectra of the parent chromophore and complex.

elements.content: A different approach is to incorporate organic electron-donor units into the ligands of transition-metal complexes, which can bring about additional strong visible absorption bands. Electron-rich groups, such as triarylamines and thioethers, give rise to intraligand charge-transfer (ILCT) transitions, which generally have higher extinction coefficients than MLCT transitions. Here the donor orbital in an ILCT transition is localized on the organic donor unit, while the acceptor orbital is a π* orbital as in an MLCT transition. There have been several studies on the effect of substitution of triphenylamine (TPA) as well as the behavior of different conjugated linkers that join the donor to the ligand.

Electron-rich groups, such as triarylamines and thioethers, give rise to intraligand charge-transfer (ILCT) transitions, which generally have higher extinction coefficients than MLCT transitions. Here the donor orbital in an ILCT transition is localized on the organic donor unit, while the acceptor orbital is a π* orbital as in an MLCT transition. There have been several studies on the effect of substitution of triphenylamine (TPA) as well as the behavior of different conjugated linkers that join the donor to the ligand.

elements.content: In this paper, we present some d6 and d8 transition-metal complexes based on previously studied 2-pyridyl-1,2,3-triazole (pytri) ligands (). The pytri ligands are synthesized conveniently with “click” chemistry. A variety of substituents can be incorporated into the complexes through the 1,2,3-triazole ring by using different azide precursors. However, these triazole substituents generally have a very limited effect on the behavior of the complexes formed because the triazole ring acts as an electronic insulator. The incorporation of electron-donating and -withdrawing groups on the triazole ring has proven to be a poor way of controlling the excited-state behavior of these complexes. Herein we report the synthesis of d6 and d8 metal complexes of a pytri ligand, where the pyridine ring is substituted with a TPA electron-donor unit rather than the triazole ring to give a ligand referred to as TPA-pytri. TPA substitution of polypyridyl ligands has previously been shown to result in strong ILCT transitions and altered photophysical behavior compared to unsubstituted ligands. A benzyl group is appended to the triazole ring of TPA-pytri, while the pytri complexes without the TPA substituent have either a hexyl group (hexpytri) or a benzyl group (Bnpytri) attached to the triazole ring ( and ).

elements.content: The triphenylamine-substituted 2-pyridyl-1,2,3-triazole (TPA-pytri) was synthesized in three steps (). 4-(Diphenylamino)­phenylboronic acid and 4-(5-bromopyridin-2-yl)-2-methylbut-3-yn-2-ol were reacted using standard palladium(0)-catalyzed Suzuki cross-coupling reaction conditions and gave compound 1 in 75% yield. The tertiary propargyl alcohol group of 1 was removed with KOH powder in toluene to provide compound 2 in 86% yield. The TPA-pytri ligand was generated from 2, benzyl bromide, and NaN3 using one-pot in situ azide formation-click conditions at room temperature in 70% yield. Increasing the temperature of the reaction to 65 °C further improved the yield (82%).
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Ligand Synthesis

The triphenylamine-substituted 2-pyridyl-1,2,3-triazole (TPA-pytri) was synthesized in three steps (). 4-(Diphenylamino)phenylboronic acid and 4-(5-bromopyridin-2-yl)-2-methylbut-3-yn-2-ol were reacted using standard palladium(0)-catalyzed Suzuki cross-coupling reaction conditions and gave compound 1 in 75% yield. The tertiary propargyl alcohol group of 1 was removed with KOH powder in toluene to provide compound 2 in 86% yield. The TPA-pytri ligand was generated from 2, benzyl bromide, and NaN3 using one-pot in situ azide formation-click conditions at room temperature in 70% yield. Increasing the temperature of the reaction to 65 °C further improved the yield (82%).

elements.content: Compounds 1 and 2 and TPA-pytri were characterized using IR, 1H and 13C NMR spectroscopies, high-resolution electrospray ionization mass spectrometry (HRESI-MS), and elemental analysis (Supporting Information, Figures S1–S9). In addition, molecular structures of 2 and TPA-pytri (cocrystallized with KOH) were determined by X-ray crystallography (Supporting Information, Figures S10–S13).
elements.clean_text: Compounds 1 and 2 and TPA-pytri were characterized using IR, 1H and 13C NMR spectroscopies, high-resolution electrospray ionization mass spectrometry (HRESI-MS), and elemental analysis (Supporting Information, Figures S1-S9). In addition, molecular structures of 2 and TPA-pytri (cocrystallized with KOH) were determined by X-ray crystallography (Supporting Information, Figures S10-S13).

elements.content: Ruthenium­(II), rhenium­(I), and platinum­(II) complexes of TPA-pytri ([Ru­(TPA-pytri)­(bpy)2]2+, [Re­(TPA-pytri)­(CO)3Br], and [Pt­(TPA-pytri)­Cl2]) were prepared using the methods previously exploited for generation of the parent pytri complexes (). The dichloroplatinum­(II) complex [Pt­(TPA-pytri)­Cl2] was reacted with phenylacetylene, triethylamine, and copper­(I) iodide in CH2Cl2. The crude product was purified on a silica gel column and gave the bis­(phenylacetylide)­platinum­(II) complex [Pt­(TPA-pytri)­(CCPh)2] in moderate yield (59%). [Pt­(hexpytri)­Cl2] and [Pt­(hexpytri)­(CCPh)2] were synthesized using analogous methods. All complexes were characterized using IR, 1H and 13C NMR spectroscopies, HRESI-MS, and elemental analysis (Supporting Information, Figures S14–S24). The molecular structures of [Ru­(TPA-pytri)­(bpy)2]2+, [Re­(TPA-pytri)­(CO)3Br], and [Pt­(TPA-pytri)­(CCPh)2] were unambiguously confirmed by X-ray crystallography (). The crystal structures of the d6 ruthenium­(II) and rhenium­(I) complexes ([Ru­(TPA-pytri)­(bpy)2]2+ and [Re­(TPA-pytri)­(CO)3Br]) display a distorted octahedral coordination environment about the metal ions. The ruthenium­(II) ion of [Ru­(TPA-pytri)­(bpy)2]2+ is coordinated to two bidentate 2,2′-bipyridine (bpy) ligands and a bidentate TPA-pytri ligand. The divalent charge of the metal ion is balanced by two noncoordinating PF6 – anions. The [Ru­(TPA-pytri)­(bpy)2]2+ cation is chiral. The crystal contains a racemic mixture of Λ and Δ enantiomers, and both enantiomers are present in the asymmetric unit. The Ru–N bond lengths and N–Ru–N angles observed in [Ru­(TPA-pytri)­(bpy)2]2+ are similar to those reported by us for analogous complexes without the TPA substituent. While the TPA substituent has little impact on the octahedral coordination environment about the ruthenium­(II) ion, it is involved in π-stacking interactions. One of the CH groups of the TPA substituent in the Δ isomer forms a CH···π interaction with the benzyl ring of the Λ isomer (Supporting Information, Figure S25). The rhenium­(I) ion of [Re­(TPA-pytri)­(CO)3Br] coordinates to a bidentate TPA-pytri ligand, three carbonyl ligands, and a bromide ligand. The carbonyl ligands adopted the expected facial arrangement about the rhenium­(I) cation, as was observed for bromidotricarbonylrhenium­(I) complexes of pytri, which were characterized by X-ray crystallography. The Re–N bond lengths and N–Re–N angles observed in [Re­(TPA-pytri)­(CO)3Br] are similar to those observed in an analogous complex without the TPA substituent. The structure of [Pt­(TPA-pytri)­(CCPh)2] displayed the expected square-planar geometry about the platinum­(II) ion with the metal bound to the bidentate TPA-pytri and two phenylacetylide ligands. Both the benzyl and TPA units of the TPA-pytri ligand are involved in the π–π and CH···π interactions between adjacent molecules (Supporting Information, Figures S26 and S27).
elements.clean_text:
Metal Complex Synthesis

Ruthenium(II), rhenium(I), and platinum(II) complexes of TPA-pytri ([Ru(TPA-pytri)(bpy)2]2+, [Re(TPA-pytri)(CO)3Br], and [Pt(TPA-pytri)Cl2]) were prepared using the methods previously exploited for generation of the parent pytri complexes (). The dichloroplatinum(II) complex [Pt(TPA-pytri)Cl2] was reacted with phenylacetylene, triethylamine, and copper(I) iodide in CH2Cl2. The crude product was purified on a silica gel column and gave the bis(phenylacetylide)platinum(II) complex [Pt(TPA-pytri)(CCPh)2] in moderate yield (59%). [Pt(hexpytri)Cl2] and [Pt(hexpytri)(CCPh)2] were synthesized using analogous methods. All complexes were characterized using IR, 1H and 13C NMR spectroscopies, HRESI-MS, and elemental analysis (Supporting Information, Figures S14-S24). The molecular structures of [Ru(TPA-pytri)(bpy)2]2+, [Re(TPA-pytri)(CO)3Br], and [Pt(TPA-pytri)(CCPh)2] were unambiguously confirmed by X-ray crystallography (). The crystal structures of the d6 ruthenium(II) and rhenium(I) complexes ([Ru(TPA-pytri)(bpy)2]2+ and [Re(TPA-pytri)(CO)3Br]) display a distorted octahedral coordination environment about the metal ions. The ruthenium(II) ion of [Ru(TPA-pytri)(bpy)2]2+ is coordinated to two bidentate 2,2'-bipyridine (bpy) ligands and a bidentate TPA-pytri ligand. The divalent charge of the metal ion is balanced by two noncoordinating PF6 - anions. The [Ru(TPA-pytri)(bpy)2]2+ cation is chiral. The crystal contains a racemic mixture of Λ and Δ enantiomers, and both enantiomers are present in the asymmetric unit. The Ru-N bond lengths and N-Ru-N angles observed in [Ru(TPA-pytri)(bpy)2]2+ are similar to those reported by us for analogous complexes without the TPA substituent. While the TPA substituent has little impact on the octahedral coordination environment about the ruthenium(II) ion, it is involved in π-stacking interactions. One of the CH groups of the TPA substituent in the Δ isomer forms a CH⋅⋅⋅π interaction with the benzyl ring of the Λ isomer (Supporting Information, Figure S25). The rhenium(I) ion of [Re(TPA-pytri)(CO)3Br] coordinates to a bidentate TPA-pytri ligand, three carbonyl ligands, and a bromide ligand. The carbonyl ligands adopted the expected facial arrangement about the rhenium(I) cation, as was observed for bromidotricarbonylrhenium(I) complexes of pytri, which were characterized by X-ray crystallography. The Re-N bond lengths and N-Re-N angles observed in [Re(TPA-pytri)(CO)3Br] are similar to those observed in an analogous complex without the TPA substituent. The structure of [Pt(TPA-pytri)(CCPh)2] displayed the expected square-planar geometry about the platinum(II) ion with the metal bound to the bidentate TPA-pytri and two phenylacetylide ligands. Both the benzyl and TPA units of the TPA-pytri ligand are involved in the π-π and CH⋅⋅⋅π interactions between adjacent molecules (Supporting Information, Figures S26 and S27).

elements.content: The electronic absorption spectra of the molecules studied in this work are presented in and summarized in . The spectrum of Bnpytri is typical of that for pytri ligands in that there is no visible absorption with the first band appearing at 280 nm (π → π* of the ligand). In striking contrast, the TPA-pytri ligand shows a strong absorption band at 350 nm, which is assigned as charge transfer from the TPA π system to the pytri π* system. In the TPA-pytri complexes, this band is red-shifted because of lowering of the pytri π* orbital energies. In the rhenium­(I) and platinum­(II) complexes, this is clearly seen. In CH2Cl2, the band appears between 398 and 421 nm with a shoulder at higher energy. The pytri complexes lacking the TPA unit (dashed lines, ) show MLCT bands that match the wavelength of this shoulder. The same applies to the ruthenium­(II) complex, but the bpy-based MLCT band overlaps with the TPA-based ILCT band, giving rise to a single broad band at 412 nm. The largest red shift of the TPA-pytri ILCT band is observed for [Pt­(TPA-pytri)­Cl2] (4800 cm–1), which implies that this metal center is the most electron-withdrawing. Resonance Raman spectroscopy and time-dependent density functional theory (TD-DFT) calculations were used to investigate the Franck–Condon states of the molecules.
elements.clean_text:
Electronic Absorption

The electronic absorption spectra of the molecules studied in this work are presented in  and summarized in . The spectrum of Bnpytri is typical of that for pytri ligands in that there is no visible absorption with the first band appearing at 280 nm (π → π* of the ligand). In striking contrast, the TPA-pytri ligand shows a strong absorption band at 350 nm, which is assigned as charge transfer from the TPA π system to the pytri π* system. In the TPA-pytri complexes, this band is red-shifted because of lowering of the pytri π* orbital energies. In the rhenium(I) and platinum(II) complexes, this is clearly seen. In CH2Cl2, the band appears between 398 and 421 nm with a shoulder at higher energy. The pytri complexes lacking the TPA unit (dashed lines, ) show MLCT bands that match the wavelength of this shoulder. The same applies to the ruthenium(II) complex, but the bpy-based MLCT band overlaps with the TPA-based ILCT band, giving rise to a single broad band at 412 nm. The largest red shift of the TPA-pytri ILCT band is observed for [Pt(TPA-pytri)Cl2] (4800 cm-1), which implies that this metal center is the most electron-withdrawing. Resonance Raman spectroscopy and time-dependent density functional theory (TD-DFT) calculations were used to investigate the Franck-Condon states of the molecules.

TD-DFT calculations using B3LYP are consistent with the absorption band assignments made above. Tables S1–S8 summarize the TD-DFT results and show Mulliken electron density differences for the first 10 electronic transitions. The frontier molecular orbitals for the rhenium­(I) complexes are shown in and in the Supporting Information for the other compounds. The MLCT bands of [Re­(Bnpytri)­(CO)3Br], [Pt­(hexpytri)­Cl2], and [Pt­(hexpytri)­(CCPh)2] consist of two separate transitions. The acceptor orbital (lowest unoccupied molecular orbital, LUMO) in each case is a π* orbital spanning the triazole and pyridine rings of the pytri ligand. The highest occupied molecular orbital (HOMO) and HOMO–1 are metal–ancillary ligand dπ orbitals. For [Pt­(hexpytri)­Cl2], d–d bands are predicted below the MLCT transitions as expected due to the weak-field chloride ligands. For the TPA-pytri complexes, the HOMO is a TPA-based π orbital, which supersedes the dπ orbitals. The LUMO extends somewhat into the phenyl ring pendant to the pyridyl ring, lowering its energy slightly. The ruthenium­(II) complexes follow the same pattern, but two bpy MLCT bands are predicted below the pytri MLCT transition. The lowest-energy strong transition for each TPA-pytri complex is predicted to be an ILCT transition from the TPA π orbital to the pytri-based π* orbital. This is what might be expected from the electronic absorption spectra for the rhenium­(I) and platinum­(II) complexes, but for the calculations of the ruthenium­(II) complex, the ILCT energy seems to be underestimated compared to the bpy MLCT transition.

elements.content: The electrochemistry of the TPA-pytri ligand and its complexes was probed using cyclic and differential-pulse voltammetry in a N,N-dimethylformamide (DMF) solution with Bu4NPF6 as the supporting electrolyte. The results are presented in with representative voltammograms in Figures S36–S37. The free TPA-pytri ligand undergoes a quasi-reversible reduction at ca. −2.1 V. The increased reversibility and occurrence at an anodic potential of 300 mV of the pytri reduction are consistent with more electron delocalization in the larger triphenylamino system. The appended TPA gives rise to a quasi-reversible oxidation process observed at 1.02 V. Predictably, the electrochemical behavior of [Re­(TPA-pytri)­(CO)3Br] closely resembles that of other rhenium tricarbonyl­(α-diimine)­halide complexes. Thus, an irreversible one-electron oxidation associated with the ReII/ReI couple is observed at E pa = +1.56 V, and a irreversible, ligand-based reduction wave at E pc = −1.58 V. For the [Ru­(TPA-pytri)­(bpy)2]2+ complex, three reversible reductions are consecutively assigned to the two bpy and third TPA-pytri ligand by comparison with [Ru­(Bnpytri)­(bpy)2]2+ and similar systems. The chemically reversible RuIII/II oxidation is observed at ca. 1.3 V, consistent with previously reported ruthenium­(II) dyes. Platinum oxidation is typically complex, often irreversible, and solvent- and electrolyte-dependent. The platinum­(II) complexes reported here display an irreversible oxidation wave at ca. 1.4 V for those with chloride ligands and at ca. 1.0 V for those with the more electron-donating acetylide ligands. The complexes with the TPA-appended pytri ligands all display an amine-associated oxidation at ca. +1.1 V (a slight anodic shift from the free ligand, consistent with coordination of the pytri component). The reversibility of this process varies with the metal and its ancillary ligands, increases with the scan rate, and shows some solvent dependence. The appearance of the amine oxidation feature before that of the metal (at more cathodic potential) is consistent with the DFT results, which show a TPA-based HOMO.

Electrochemistry

The electrochemistry of the TPA-pytri ligand and its complexes was probed using cyclic and differential-pulse voltammetry in a N,N-dimethylformamide (DMF) solution with Bu4NPF6 as the supporting electrolyte. The results are presented in  with representative voltammograms in Figures S36-S37. The free TPA-pytri ligand undergoes a quasi-reversible reduction at ca. -2.1 V. The increased reversibility and occurrence at an anodic potential of 300 mV of the pytri reduction are consistent with more electron delocalization in the larger triphenylamino system. The appended TPA gives rise to a quasi-reversible oxidation process observed at 1.02 V. Predictably, the electrochemical behavior of [Re(TPA-pytri)(CO)3Br] closely resembles that of other rhenium tricarbonyl(α-diimine)halide complexes. Thus, an irreversible one-electron oxidation associated with the ReII/ReI couple is observed at E pa = +1.56 V, and a  irreversible, ligand-based reduction wave at E pc = -1.58 V. For the [Ru(TPA-pytri)(bpy)2]2+ complex, three reversible reductions are consecutively assigned to the two bpy and third TPA-pytri ligand by comparison with [Ru(Bnpytri)(bpy)2]2+  and similar systems. The chemically reversible RuIII/II oxidation is observed at ca. 1.3 V, consistent with previously reported ruthenium(II) dyes. Platinum oxidation is typically complex, often irreversible, and solvent- and electrolyte-dependent. The platinum(II) complexes reported here display an irreversible oxidation wave at ca. 1.4 V for those with chloride ligands and at ca. 1.0 V for those with the more electron-donating acetylide ligands. The complexes with the TPA-appended pytri ligands all display an amine-associated oxidation at ca. +1.1 V (a slight anodic shift from the free ligand, consistent with coordination of the pytri component). The reversibility of this process varies with the metal and its ancillary ligands, increases with the scan rate, and shows some solvent dependence. The appearance of the amine oxidation feature before that of the metal (at more cathodic potential) is consistent with the DFT results, which show a TPA-based HOMO.

Resonance Raman spectroscopy was used to probe the Franck–Condon states of the TPA-pytri and pytri complexes. Vibrational modes, which mimic changes in the molecular structure that occur during an electronic transition, are enhanced when a laser wavelength coincident with that electronic transition is used to generate Raman scattering. Laser wavelengths between 351 and 458 nm were used to probe the M­(L)­LCT (MLLCT is metal-and-ligand-to-ligand charge transfer, see below) and ILCT bands. Nonresonant spectra were recorded at 1064 or 785 nm excitation for comparison. Simulated nonresonant Raman spectra were generated from DFT calculations in order to test the effectiveness of the modeling. From these calculations, the modes may be assigned, and it is these assignments that are used in the analysis of the resonance Raman spectra. TD-DFT calculations show that for both the M­(L)­LCT and ILCT bands the same π* acceptor orbital localized on the pyridyl and triazole rings is involved. Therefore, vibrations of these two rings should be enhanced for either type of transition. Vibrations of the TPA unit should be enhanced for an ILCT transition, and vibrations of ancillary ligands should be enhanced for M­(L)­LCT transitions (CC or CO stretches especially). However, the interpretation of the spectra is not always so simple in practice.
elements.clean_text:
Resonance Raman Spectroscopy

Resonance Raman spectroscopy was used to probe the Franck-Condon states of the TPA-pytri and pytri complexes. Vibrational modes, which mimic changes in the molecular structure that occur during an electronic transition, are enhanced when a laser wavelength coincident with that electronic transition is used to generate Raman scattering. Laser wavelengths between 351 and 458 nm were used to probe the M(L)LCT (MLLCT is metal-and-ligand-to-ligand charge transfer, see below) and ILCT bands. Nonresonant spectra were recorded at 1064 or 785 nm excitation for comparison. Simulated nonresonant Raman spectra were generated from DFT calculations in order to test the effectiveness of the modeling. From these calculations, the modes may be assigned, and it is these assignments that are used in the analysis of the resonance Raman spectra. TD-DFT calculations show that for both the M(L)LCT and ILCT bands the same π* acceptor orbital localized on the pyridyl and triazole rings is involved. Therefore, vibrations of these two rings should be enhanced for either type of transition. Vibrations of the TPA unit should be enhanced for an ILCT transition, and vibrations of ancillary ligands should be enhanced for M(L)LCT transitions (CC or CO stretches especially). However, the interpretation of the spectra is not always so simple in practice.

elements.content: The resonance Raman spectra of [Re­(Bnpytri)­(CO)3Br] (Figure S41), which has a pair of MLCT transitions and no ILCT band, show enhancement of several pytri-based modes at 1000, 1026, 1281, 1566, 1585, and 1621 cm–1. All carbonyl stretches are observed in the nonresonant spectrum, but only the symmetric mode at 2030 cm–1 is enhanced when the MLCT band is probed. At wavelengths longer than 375 nm, the resonance Raman spectra are very weak due to loss of resonance and onset of emission.

All carbonyl stretches are observed in the nonresonant spectrum, but only the symmetric mode at 2030 cm-1 is enhanced when the MLCT band is probed. At wavelengths longer than 375 nm, the resonance Raman spectra are very weak due to loss of resonance and onset of emission.

elements.content: Between 351 and 375 nm, the spectra of [Re­(TPA-pytri)­(CO)3Br] () show enhancements of several bands that correspond to bands seen in the [Re­(Bnpytri)­(CO)3Br] spectra. These are modes associated with the triazole and pyridine rings as well as the pendant phenyl ring (a–c) and the symmetric carbonyl stretch. The band at 1618 cm–1 shows significant amplitude on the NPh2 group of the TPA substituent and is yet strongest at shorter wavelengths when the MLCT band is being probed (d). However, other modes that are associated with the TPA group are strongest at wavelengths longer than 375 nm, as expected for an ILCT transition.

elements.content: The resonance Raman spectra of [Ru­(Bnpytri)­(bpy)2]2+ are reported in Figure S42. We showed previously that [Ru­(Bnpytri)­(bpy)2]2+ has a resonance Raman spectrum nearly identical with that of the prototypical [Ru­(bpy)3]2+ with 458 nm excitation. Modes associated with bpy (1026, 1039, 1171, 1275, 1317, 1489, 1562, and 1605 cm–1) are strongly enhanced as expected for an MLCT transition involving a π*orbital of bpy. The spectra from 407 to 448 nm are nearly identical with the spectrum with 458 nm excitation, although there are a few additional bands enhanced (1263 and 1580 cm–1) in the 413 and 407 nm resonant spectra. These are associated with the pytri ligand and become stronger with 351 and 356 nm excitation along with other pytri modes (1623, 1064, and 995 cm–1), while bpy modes are weaker. This suggests that there is an MLCT transition involving the pytri ligand around 350 nm. This is also predicted by TD-DFT but not easily seen in the UV–vis spectrum (see above).

We showed previously that [Ru(Bnpytri)(bpy)2]2+ has a resonance Raman spectrum nearly identical with that of the prototypical [Ru(bpy)3]2+ with 458 nm excitation. Modes associated with bpy (1026, 1039, 1171, 1275, 1317, 1489, 1562, and 1605 cm-1) are strongly enhanced as expected for an MLCT transition involving a π*orbital of bpy. The spectra from 407 to 448 nm are nearly identical with the spectrum with 458 nm excitation, although there are a few additional bands enhanced (1263 and 1580 cm-1) in the 413 and 407 nm resonant spectra. These are associated with the pytri ligand and become stronger with 351 and 356 nm excitation along with other pytri modes (1623, 1064, and 995 cm-1), while bpy modes are weaker. This suggests that there is an MLCT transition involving the pytri ligand around 350 nm. This is also predicted by TD-DFT but not easily seen in the UV-vis spectrum (see above).

elements.content: The Raman spectra of [Ru­(TPA-pytri)­(bpy)2]2+ () are more difficult to interpret because of the presence of several overlapping electronic transitions. The bpy bands are not expected to be perturbed significantly by introduction of the TPA unit. All of the bpy modes from [Ru­(Bnpytri)­(bpy)2]2+ can been seen in the [Ru­(TPA-pytri)­(bpy)2]2+ spectra except the 1605 cm–1 mode, which is likely obscured by a very strong TPA-pytri band at 1610 cm–1. As in [Ru­(Bnpytri)­(bpy)2]2+, these modes are dominant with 448 and 458 nm excitation wavelengths, which shows that the bpy-based MLCT transition is unperturbed by the TPA group. Several TPA-pytri modes (1002, 1143, 1199, 1300, 1393, 1554, 1584, and 1593 cm–1) can, however, be observed at these wavelengths as well. These then become the strongest modes with 407 and 413 nm excitation. Contrary to the TD-DFT calculations for this complex, the resonance Raman enhancement pattern indicates that the ILCT transition is at higher energy than the bpy MLCT transition. The 1476, 1584, and 1615 cm–1 bands are only seen below 407 nm excitation and are associated with the pytri-based MLCT transition around 350 nm as in [Ru­(Bnpytri)­(bpy)2]2+.

elements.content: The resonance Raman spectra of [Pt­(hexpytri)­Cl2] (Figure S43) show enhancement of the pyridyl-triazole modes, which are comparable to those of [Re­(Bnpytri)­(CO)3Br]. Both complexes have MLCT bands at about the same wavelength, but because of the weak-field Cl– ligands, the presence of d–d bands is also possible below the MLCT band of [Pt­(hexpytri)­Cl2]. These are not seen in the electronic absorption spectrum but may be responsible for the weakening of some of the Raman mode intensities with 407 and 413 nm excitation due to resonant deenhancement. The same pattern was seen in the related inverse pytri complexes.

These are not seen in the electronic absorption spectrum but may be responsible for the weakening of some of the Raman mode intensities with 407 and 413 nm excitation due to resonant deenhancement. The same pattern was seen in the related inverse pytri complexes.

elements.content: The resonance Raman spectra of [Pt­(TPA-pytri)­Cl2] are reported in Figure S44. Because the electronic absorption spectra of [Re­(TPA-pytri)­(CO)3Br]) and [Pt­(TPA-pytri)­Cl2] are similar, the resonance Raman enhancement patterns are also similar. As with [Re­(TPA-pytri)­(CO)3Br], modes associated with the triazole, pyridine, and phenyl ring acceptors are enhanced at all wavelengths. The band at 1625 cm–1 is equivalent to the [Re­(TPA-pytri)­(CO)3Br] band at 1618 cm–1, which involves vibration of the NPh2 group. This band is likewise strongest at 351 nm, where the MLCT band is probed.

Because the electronic absorption spectra of [Re(TPA-pytri)(CO)3Br]) and [Pt(TPA-pytri)Cl2] are similar, the resonance Raman enhancement patterns are also similar. As with [Re(TPA-pytri)(CO)3Br], modes associated with the triazole, pyridine, and phenyl ring acceptors are enhanced at all wavelengths. The band at 1625 cm-1 is equivalent to the [Re(TPA-pytri)(CO)3Br] band at 1618 cm-1, which involves vibration of the NPh2 group. This band is likewise strongest at 351 nm, where the MLCT band is probed.

elements.content: The Raman spectra of [Pt­(hexpytri)­(CCPh)2] () show enhancement of several pyridine and triazole modes, which correspond to those of [Re­(Bnpytri)­(CO)3Br]. Additionally, there are two very strong CC stretching modes at 2119 and 2130 cm–1. TD-DFT calculations predict that the metal-and-ligand-to-ligand charge transfer (MLLCT) band of [Pt­(hexpytri)­(CCPh)2] is composed of two MLLCT transitions that share the same acceptor orbital (LUMO). The lower-energy transition involves the HOMO, which has more electron density on the acetylide trans to the pyridine compared to the acetylide trans to the triazole ring. This is reversed for the higher-energy transition, which involves HOMO–1. This may explain the changes in the relative intensities of the two acetylide stretching modes at different excitation wavelengths (Figure S45). According to DFT calculations, the higher-frequency mode at 2130 cm–1 has more amplitude on the acetylide trans to the pyridine ring and is more strongly enhanced at the longer excitation wavelengths. When the low-energy portion of the MLLCT band is probed, the 2119 cm–1 mode becomes more strongly enhanced because it has more amplitude on the other acetylide. The intensities of the other modes are mostly unchanged at these excitation wavelengths.

elements.content: Unlike [Pt­(hexpytri)­(CCPh)2], the resonance Raman spectra of [Pt­(TPA-pytri)­(CCPh)2] (Figure S47) show no enhancement of acetylide stretching bands at any wavelength, although they are very strong in the nonresonant spectrum. Other band enhancements in the resonant spectra are similar to what is seen in the other TPA-pytri complexes. At all wavelengths, the ILCT transition appears to dominate. This is in contrast to [Re­(TPA-pytri)­(CO)3Br], where CO band enhancement associated with an MLCT transition is observed. This is surprising because carbonyl modes are generally weaker than acetylide modes and the MLCT absorption band for the acetylide complex is much more intense. This type of behavior has been observed in a rhenium­(I) complex of TPA-substituted dppz in which no CO stretching modes are observed at any excitation wavelength.
elements.clean_text: Unlike [Pt(hexpytri)(CCPh)2], the resonance Raman spectra of [Pt(TPA-pytri)(CCPh)2] (Figure S47) show no enhancement of acetylide stretching bands at any wavelength, although they are very strong in the nonresonant spectrum. Other band enhancements in the resonant spectra are similar to what is seen in the other TPA-pytri complexes. At all wavelengths, the ILCT transition appears to dominate. This is in contrast to [Re(TPA-pytri)(CO)3Br], where CO band enhancement associated with an MLCT transition is observed. This is surprising because carbonyl modes are generally weaker than acetylide modes and the MLCT absorption band for the acetylide complex is much more intense. This type of behavior has been observed in a rhenium(I) complex of TPA-substituted dppz in which no CO stretching modes are observed at any excitation wavelength.

elements.content: Emission from [Re­(Bnpytri)­(CO)3Br] is broad and structureless like most rhenium­(I) complexes. A rhenium­(I) complex with the same pytri ligand with chloride instead of bromide as the ancillary ligand has been studied previously. The change in halogen has only a subtle effect on the emission quantum yield, lifetime, and wavelength. [Re­(TPA-pytri)­(CO)3Br] has an emission spectrum that is red-shifted compared to [Re­(Bnpytri)­(CO)3Br] but has a similar quantum yield. The emission lifetime was shorter than the time resolution of the instrument. TA spectra show a long-lived dark state (τ = 10 μs) with a broad absorption band at about 700 nm, which is indicative of an oxidized TPA group (Figure S49). This is consistent with the formation of a 3ILCT state.

elements.content: [Pt­(hexpytri)­Cl2] is not emissive in fluid solution, which is typical for this class of compound, where low-lying d–d states result in very short excited-state lifetimes. Surprisingly, the corresponding TPA-substituted complex [Pt­(TPA-pytri)­Cl2] is emissive under the same conditions. To our knowledge, there is only one other emissive platinum­(II) dichloride complex reported in the literature. The short excited-state lifetime and insensitivity to dissolved O2 suggest an emissive 1ILCT state.

The short excited-state lifetime and insensitivity to dissolved O2 suggest an emissive 1ILCT state.

elements.content: Replacement of the chloride ligands in [Pt­(hexpytri)­Cl2] with more strongly donating phenylacetylide ligands gives [Pt­(hexpytri)­(CCPh)2], which is emissive in fluid solution because of the higher-lying d–d states being unable to deactivate the MLCT emission. The emission lifetime (16 ns) and Stokes shift (7460 cm–1) are comparable to that of similar bpy-based complexes, which suggests that emission is from a 3MLLCT state. [Pt­(TPA-pytri)­(CCPh)2] has an emission spectrum that is red-shifted compared to [Pt­(hexpytri)­(CCPh)2] and blue-shifted compared to [Pt­(TPA-pytri)­Cl2]. The transient emission and absorption data are very similar to those of [Re­(TPA-pytri)­(CO)3Br]. The emissive excited-state lifetime was too short to measure, but a long-lived dark state with a lifetime of 2.7 μs is observed. The absorption at 700 nm indicates that this is a 3ILCT state (Figure S52).

elements.content: [Ru­(TPA-pytri)­(bpy)2]2+ shows a very weak emission signal at the same wavelength as the simpler [Ru­(Bnpytri)­(bpy)2]2+ studied previously. The quantum yields for two compounds are about 30 times smaller than for [Ru­(bpy)3]2+ under the same conditions. We were unable to probe the excited-state dynamics with nanosecond TA because of very short lifetimes. This is likely due to the rapid nonradiative decay of the 3MLCT state through d–d states. Resonance Raman spectra suggested that the lowest singlet state is a bpy-based MLCT state. If the ILCT state were lower in energy, one might expect emission from this state instead. We cannot reliably assign the emissive excited state, but a bpy-based MLCT state or TPA-pytri-based ILCT state is most plausible.

elements.content: The rhenium­(I) and platinum­(II) bis­(phenylacetylide) compounds were probed on both the nanosecond and picosecond time scales using TRIR spectroscopy. The strong IR νCO and νCC bands inform on changes in the electron density around the metal centers after photoexcitation. Ultrafast TRIR made it possible to probe the early excited-state dynamics, which we could not observe with nanosecond transient emission and absorption spectroscopy.
elements.clean_text:
Time-Resolved Infrared (TRIR) Spectroscopy

The rhenium(I) and platinum(II) bis(phenylacetylide) compounds were probed on both the nanosecond and picosecond time scales using TRIR spectroscopy. The strong IR νCO and νCC bands inform on changes in the electron density around the metal centers after photoexcitation. Ultrafast TRIR made it possible to probe the early excited-state dynamics, which we could not observe with nanosecond transient emission and absorption spectroscopy.

elements.content: Representative TRIR time delays of [Re­(Bnpytri)­(CO)3Br] and [Re­(TPA-pytri)­(CO)3Br] are shown . [Re­(Bnpytri)­(CO)3Br] shows bleaching of the parent bands at 2027, 1928, and 1902 cm–1, concomitant with the formation of new broad product bands at ca. 2038 and 1954 cm–1. These features rapidly decay (3 ± 1 ps) to form new bands at 2053, 1982, and 1959 cm–1 (see Figure S55 for kinetic traces). A further 28 (± 4 ps) process is observed that manifests spectrally as a slight growth of all bands (the parent bleaches are unaffected); this may be due to vibrational cooling. Finally, these bands decay, concurrent with parent re-formation, with a lifetime of 240 (± 10 ns) (see Figure S56 for nanosecond spectra). This is likely somewhat shorter than what is observed with transient emission spectroscopy because of the higher concentrations used for TRIR, causing self-quenching. As the excited-state bands are shifted to higher energies, they can be assigned to a 3MLCT state. The shift is a manifestation of decreased back-bonding to the carbonyl antibonding orbitals due to a shift in the electron density away from the metal. The shift in the high-energy symmetric stretching mode (+26 cm–1) is significantly smaller than that observed for [Re­(bpy)­(CO)3Cl] (40 cm–1), suggesting a comparatively lower degree of charge separation in the MLCT state.

elements.content: Immediately after photoexcitation, the TRIR spectra of [Re­(TPA-pytri)­(CO)3Br] show bleaching of the parent bands (2028, 1926, and 1900 cm–1) and the appearance of a band at 2004 cm–1 (with a shoulder at ca. 2015 cm–1). Analogous bands are present in the low-wavenumber part of the spectrum; however, they show significant overlap with the parent bands, making their exact analysis difficult. Focusing on the higher-wavenumber features, a slight shift to higher energy is observed with a time constant of 8 (± 4 ps), which is attributed to vibrational cooling. After this, a decay of the band at 2004 cm–1, as well as a growth of the band at 2015 cm–1, is evident, with corresponding features at 1917 and 1888 cm–1 in the low-wavenumber region of the spectrum. Both processes can be fitted with a time constant of ca. 140 ps (see Figure S57 for kinetic traces). From the nanosecond spectra, these features can be fitted to a final decay lifetime of 440 ns. This is likely somewhat shorter than that observed in the TA spectra because of the higher concentrations used for TRIR.

elements.content: The shift of νCO in the excited state for [Re­(TPA-pytri)­(CO)3Br] is to lower wavenumber, indicating increased electron density in the carbonyl antibonding orbitals. The magnitude of the shift is indicative of the nature of the excited state, where relatively small (2–12 cm–1) shifts are indicative of ligand-centered π,π* states, while greater shifts are observed for charge-separated and electrochemically reduced species.

elements.content: On this basis, the initial shift upon photoexcitation of −24 cm–1 is strong evidence for the formation of an ILCT state from the TPA donor orbital to the pytri-based π* orbital, as is also predicted using DFT. The subsequently formed bands show a smaller shift from the parent (−13 cm–1 for the symmetric stretching mode), which is consistent with formation of an ILCT state with a lower degree of charge separation or a π,π* state in which back-bonding through the metal is decreased. Such a sequestering of electrons away from the chelating nitrogen atom is not without precedent and has been observed in TRIR studies of complexes containing the electron acceptor N-methyl-4,4′-bipyridinium, which sequesters the excited electron away from the chelating nitrogen atoms. A plot of the spin density (Figure S59) for triplet [Re­(TPA-pytri)­(CO)3Br] and unrestricted DFT optimization show what appears to be an ILCT state. The shift in the frequency of the symmetric stretching mode is accurately predicted by the calculations (Figure S61).

elements.content: Immediately upon photoexcitation of [Pt­(hexpytri)­(CCPh)2], bleaching of the 2130 and 2119 cm–1 parent bands is apparent. Broad positive features in the difference spectrum appear at ca. 2140 and 2060 cm–1, and a significant shift in the baseline occurs (). These results are similar to what has been reported by Sazanovich et al. for the analogous complex [Pt­((COOEt)2bpy)­(C7H15CCPh)2] [(COOEt)2bpy = (2,2′-bipyridine)-4,4′-diethyl ester, C7H15CCPh = 1-ethynyl-4-heptylbenzene], where the excited state was assigned as MLLCT. In their experiment, the CC stretch was significantly broadened and shifted to ca. 1800 cm–1. Because this is outside our collected experimental region, we were unable to observe this band. An unrestricted DFT calculation (Figure S62) for [Pt­(hexpytri)­(CCPh)2] predicts shifts in the νCC frequencies of −315 and −82 cm–1, which is consistent with the findings of Sazanovich et al. and our results.

elements.content: This is markedly different from the low shifts observed in the experiment carried out by Whittle et al., where the excited states were assigned as MLCT. The differences can be ascribed to the relative degree of involvement of the acetylide ligands and platinum d orbitals as electron donors in the excited state. An MLCT state is expected to show shifts in νCC to higher frequency due to decreased back-bonding by the metal, while an MLLCT state is expected to show shifts to lower frequency because of the loss of an electron from a CC π-bonding orbital. As such, with reference to this previous work, we assign the lowest excited state of [Pt­(hexpytri)­(CCPh)2] as MLLCT. The observed excited state features decay with a lifetime of ca. 15 ns to reform the parent (see Figure S63).

elements.content: The TRIR spectra of [Pt­(TPA-pytri)­(CCPh)2] are shown in . Upon photoexcitation, a bleach of the parent bands at 2125 and 2114 cm–1, as well as the appearance of a broad feature shifted to lower energy, is apparent. The latter decays (ca. 25 ps) and new bands grow in at 2117 and 2106 cm–1 (ca. 1 and 20 ps), which return to the baseline with a lifetime of ca. 500 ns, concurrent with the re-formation of the parent bands (see Figure S65). These new bands are shifted to slightly lower wavenumbers compared to the parent bleaches. As discussed above, small shifts to higher wavenumbers are indicative of MLCT states (decreased the electron density in the CC antibonding orbitals), while MLLCT states are associated with large shifts and broadening of the νCC bands. Thus, the shifts to lower energy observed here indicate a slight increase in the electron density in the CC antibonding orbitals, which is consistent with the presence of either a π,π* or ILCT state. Analogous to νCO shifts of the well-studied [Re­(CO)3] motif, the magnitude of the shift of the νCC bands is expected to be larger for an ILCT state compared to a π,π* state. Unrestricted DFT calculations show that the spin density of triplet [Pt­(TPA-pytri)­(CCPh)2] is localized on the TPA-pytri ligand (Figure S67). Shifts of −8 cm–1 for both νCC bands that match the experimental results are predicted.

elements.content: summarizes the excited states that are observed spectroscopically for these eight complexes. The TRIR data show that [Re­(Bnpytri)­(CO)3Br] possesses a lowest-energy excited state that is typical of MLCT character, where CO back-bonding is decreased compared with that of the ground state due to oxidation of the [Re­(CO)3] center. Upon introduction of the TPA substituent, the MLCT state is replaced by an ILCT state. The earliest detectable excited state of [Re­(TPA-pytri)­(CO)3Br] has increased CO back-bonding compared with the ground state due to increased electron density on the [Re­(CO)3] center caused by oxidation of the TPA substituent and concomitant reduction on the pytri ligand. It decays with a time constant of 140 ps to form another state of similar character with a smaller degree of charge separation. On the basis of the TRIR νCO shift of 12 cm–1, this new state may be attributed to either a π,π* or ILCT state. A similar switch is observed for the platinum acetylide complexes. [Pt­(hexpytri)­(CCPh)2] shows formation of an MLLCT state, in which the primary electron donors are the phenylacetylide ligands with some contribution from platinum d orbitals. This results in very large shifts in the νCC bands to lower frequencies, which are outside of the spectral window used. [Pt­(TPA-pytri)­(CCPh)2] shows a behavior very similar to that of [Re­(TPA-pytri)­(CO)3Br]. The excited state detected by TRIR has weakened the CC bonds because of increased electron density on the metal, as expected for an ILCT state.

elements.content:
Summary of the Excited States Observed with Resonance Raman, TA, TRIR, and Emission Spectroscopies detected excited state complex FC state I II [Re(Bnpytri)(CO)3Br] MLCT MLCT [Re(TPA-pytri)(CO)3Br] MLCT, ILCT ILCT ILCT/π,π* [Ru(Bnpytri)(bpy)2]2+ MLCT (pytri), MLCT (bpy) MLCT (bpy) [Ru(TPA-pytri)(bpy)2]2+ ILCT, MLCT (pytri), MLCT (bpy) MLCT (bpy)/ILCT [Pt(hexpytri)Cl2] MLCT [Pt(TPA-pytri)Cl2] ILCT ILCT [Pt(hexpytri)(CCPh)2] MLLCT MLLCT [Pt(TPA-pytri)(CCPh)2] ILCT ILCT ILCT/π,π*

Ambiguous assignment due to the short lifetime and lack of TRIR data.

A series of d6 and d8 transition-metal pytri complexes were synthesized and characterized with computational chemistry and spectroscopic techniques. Substitution of the pyridine ring with a TPA electron donor unit results in improved visible-light absorption over unsubstituted pytri complexes. Resonance Raman spectroscopy shows that this is due to ILCT transitions within the TPA-pytri ligand. In [Re­(TPA-pytri)­(CO)3Br], [Pt­(TPA-pytri)­Cl2], and [Pt­(TPA-pytri)­(CCPh)2], this is the lowest-energy transition. These complexes form emissive ILCT states even in the case of the weak-field dichloroplatinum­(II) complex. Only one other dichloroplatinum­(II) complex is known to be emissive in fluid solution because of deactivating d–d states. Resonance Raman spectra show that the lowest electronic transition of the RuII TPA-pytri complex is MLCT in nature and that an ILCT transition is at somewhat higher energy. Both the substituted and unsubstituted ruthenium­(II) complexes have very short lifetimes due to decay through d–d states. [Re­(TPA-pytri)­(CO)3Br] and [Pt­(TPA-pytri)­(CCPh)2] form long-lived dark states that do not occur in [Ru­(TPA-pytri)­(bpy)2]2+ and [Pt­(TPA-pytri)­Cl2] because of the relative inaccessibility of the d–d states. The excited states of [Re­(TPA-pytri)­(CO)3Br] and [Pt­(TPA-pytri)­(CCPh)2] were interrogated with picosecond and nanosecond TRIR spectroscopy; these show shifts in the CC and CO stretching bands to lower frequencies consistent with the formation of ILCT states. The corresponding unsubstituted pytri complexes show typical MLCT/MLLCT behavior.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

A series of d6 and d8 transition-metal pytri complexes were synthesized and characterized with computational chemistry and spectroscopic techniques. Substitution of the pyridine ring with a TPA electron donor unit results in improved visible-light absorption over unsubstituted pytri complexes. Resonance Raman spectroscopy shows that this is due to ILCT transitions within the TPA-pytri ligand. In [Re(TPA-pytri)(CO)3Br], [Pt(TPA-pytri)Cl2], and [Pt(TPA-pytri)(CCPh)2], this is the lowest-energy transition. These complexes form emissive ILCT states even in the case of the weak-field dichloroplatinum(II) complex. Only one other dichloroplatinum(II) complex is known to be emissive in fluid solution because of deactivating d-d states. Resonance Raman spectra show that the lowest electronic transition of the RuII TPA-pytri complex is MLCT in nature and that an ILCT transition is at somewhat higher energy. Both the substituted and unsubstituted ruthenium(II) complexes have very short lifetimes due to decay through d-d states. [Re(TPA-pytri)(CO)3Br] and [Pt(TPA-pytri)(CCPh)2] form long-lived dark states that do not occur in [Ru(TPA-pytri)(bpy)2]2+ and [Pt(TPA-pytri)Cl2] because of the relative inaccessibility of the d-d states. The excited states of [Re(TPA-pytri)(CO)3Br] and [Pt(TPA-pytri)(CCPh)2] were interrogated with picosecond and nanosecond TRIR spectroscopy; these show shifts in the CC and CO stretching bands to lower frequencies consistent with the formation of ILCT states. The corresponding unsubstituted pytri complexes show typical MLCT/MLLCT behavior.

elements.content: All reagents were laboratory-reagent-grade or better and were used as received. Dry deaerated CH2Cl2 was obtained by passing the solvents through an activated alumina column on a PureSolv solvent purification system (Innovative Technologies, Inc., Chantilly, VA). A CEM S-class microwave reactor was used to carry out microwave-enhanced reactions. All NMR spectra were recorded at 298 K. One-dimensional (1H and 13C) and two-dimensional (gCOSY, TOCSY, HSQCAD, and gHMBCAD) NMR spectra were recorded either on a Varian/Agilent 400-MR or Varian/Agilent 500 MHz AR spectrometer. All chemical shifts (δ) are reported in parts per million (ppm). Coupling constants (J) are reported in hertz. 1H NMR chemical shifts are referenced to residual solvent peaks (CHCl3, 1H δ 7.26 ppm; CD2HCN, 1H δ 1.94 ppm; DMSO-d 5, 1H δ 2.50 ppm; DMF-d 6, 1H δ 2.75 ppm). 13C NMR chemical shifts are referenced to the solvent peak (CDCl3,13C δ 77.16 ppm; CD3CN, 13C δ 1.32 ppm; DMSO-d 6, 13C δ 39.52 ppm). The abbreviation ABq indicates an AB quartet NMR signal. HRESI-MS spectra were recorded on a Bruker micrOTOF-Q spectrometer. The mass spectrometer was calibrated using an external calibrant of sodium formate clusters. Elemental analyses were performed at the Campbell Microanalytical Laboratory, University of Otago.

elements.content:
Electronic absorption spectra were recorded on an USB2000+UV–vis–ES (Ocean Optics) in HPLC-grade dichloromethane.

Steady-state emission spectra were recorded on a SP2150i spectrograph (Princeton Instruments) with 300 grooves mm–1 grating and PiXis 100 B CCD (Princeton Instruments). Samples were excited at 90° by a 355 nm (Cobolt AB, Solna, Sweden) or 448 nm (CrystaLaser, Reno, NV) diode-pumped solid-state (DPSS) laser at 15 or 25 mW, respectively. An excitation of 448 nm was used for TPA-pytri complexes to avoid the possibility of artifacts due to trace amounts of free ligand. [Ru­(bpy)3]­Cl2 in air-saturated H2O was used as a quantum yield standard. Samples were sparged with argon for 15 min before measurements were taken, and a TC125 temperature controller (Quantum Northwest) was used to maintain a constant sample temperature of 298 K. Quantum yield errors are ±10%.

elements.content: Excited-state lifetimes were obtained from transient emission and absorption spectra acquired with an LP920 flash photolysis system (Edinburgh Instruments) using the 355 nm pulsed output of a Brilliant (Quantel) Nd:YAG laser for excitation and a R928 photomultiplier tube (Hamamatsu) for detection. The detection of long-lived triplets was found to be extremely sensitive to temperature and dissolved oxygen. As with the quantum yield measurements, samples were sparged with argon for 15 min before measurements were taken, and a temperature controller was used to maintain a constant temperature of 298 K.

elements.content: Nonresonant Raman spectra were acquired at either 1064 or 785 nm using solid samples pressed into aluminum divots. A MultiRAM Fourier transform Raman spectrometer (Bruker) equipped with a 1064 nm Nd:YAG laser and a D418T liquid-nitrogen-cooled germanium detector was used for most samples. The laser power was between 30 and 100 mW, and the resolution was set to 1 cm–1. Nonresonant spectra of [Re­(Bnpytri)­(CO)3Br] were collected at 785 nm using a previously described setup.

elements.content: Resonance Raman spectra were recorded using a previously described setup. Solutions were 1–5 mM in spectroscopic-grade dichloromethane. Excitation wavelengths of 351, 356, 407, and 413 nm were obtained from a krypton-ion laser (Coherent). An excitation of 488 nm was from an argon-ion laser (Coherent). Excitations of 375, 448, and 458 nm were provided by DPSS lasers (CrystaLaser or Cobolt AB). The laser power at the samples was 10–30 mW.

elements.content: TRIR spectroscopy was carried out at the University of Nottingham on an apparatus that was described previously. Briefly, the output from a commercial Ti:sapphire oscillator (MaiTai)/regenerative amplifier system (Spitfire Pro, Spectra Physics, 800 nm, 150 fs) is split and used to generate 355 nm pump pulses and a tunable mid-IR pulse with a spectral bandwidth of 180 cm–1 and a pulse energy of ca. 2 μJ at 2000 cm–1. A portion of the IR pulse is reflected onto a single-element mercury–cadmium telluride (MCT) detector (Kolmar Technology) to serve as a reference, and the remainder serves as the probe beam, which is focused and overlaps with the pump beam at the sample position. The 355 nm pump pulse is optically delayed (up to 3 ns) by a translation stage (LMA Actuator, Aerotech) and focused onto the sample with a quartz lens. The focus spot of the probe beam was adjusted to be slightly smaller than that of the pump beam in order to ensure that the area probed corresponds to excited molecules. The broad-band-transmitted probe pulse is detected with an MCT array detector (Infrared Associates), which consists of 128 elements (1 mm high and 0.25 mm wide). The array detector is mounted in the focal plane of a 250 mm IR spectrograph (DK240, Spectral Products) with a 150 grooves mm–1 grating, resulting in a spectral resolution of ca. 4 cm–1 at 2000 cm–1. The signals from the array detector elements and the single-element detector are amplified with a 144-channel amplifier and digitized by a 16-bit analogue-to-digital converter (IR-0144, Infrared Systems Development Corp.). A Harrick flowing solution cell with 2-mm-thick CaF2 windows and a path length of 350 μm is mounted on a motorized cell mount that moves the cell rapidly in x and y dimensions throughout the experiment. Consequently, each laser pulse illuminates a different volume of the sample, reducing the heating and degradation of the sample solution.

elements.content: For the ns-TRIR experiments, the output of a Q-switched Nd:YVO4 laser (355 nm) was used as the pump. This was synchronized to the Spitfire Pro amplifier, and the delay was controlled by a pulse generator (DG535, Stanford Research Systems), allowing delays from 0.5 ns to 100 μs to be used.

elements.content: All DFT calculations were performed using Gaussian 09 with the B3LYP functional accompanied by the polarizable continuum model in CH2Cl2. The LANL2DZ effective core potential basis set was used for all metals and the 6-31G­(d) basis set for all other atoms. Simulated Raman spectra were generated from frequency calculations after structural optimization as explained previously. Frequencies were scaled by a factor of 0.975. The hexyl chain of the hexpytri ligand was modeled as a methyl group.
elements.clean_text:
Computational Methods

All DFT calculations were performed using Gaussian 09  with the B3LYP functional accompanied by the polarizable continuum model in CH2Cl2. The LANL2DZ effective core potential basis set was used for all metals and the 6-31G(d) basis set for all other atoms. Simulated Raman spectra were generated from frequency calculations after structural optimization as explained previously. Frequencies were scaled by a factor of 0.975. The hexyl chain of the hexpytri ligand was modeled as a methyl group.

elements.content: A mixture of 4-(5-bromopyridin-2-yl)-2-methylbut-3-yn-2-ol (402 mg, 1.67 mmol, 1 equiv), 4-(diphenylamino)­phenylboronic acid (968 mg, 3.35 mmol, 2 equiv), and catalyst [Pd­(1,1′-bis­(diphenylphosphino)­ferrocene)­Cl2]·CH2Cl2 (57 mg, 70 μmol, 0.04 equiv) in 1,2-dimethoxyethane (15 mL) was degassed with nitrogen gas for 25 min. Aqueous sodium carbonate solution (1 M, 3.3 mL, 2 equiv) and aqueous sodium hydroxide solution (3 M, 1.1 mL, 2 equiv) were added. elements.content: X-ray data for 2, TPA-pytri·KOH, [Ru­(TPA-pytri)­(bpy)2]­(PF6)2, fac-[Re­(TPA-pytri)­(CO)3Br], and [Pt­(TPA-pytri)­(CCPh)2] were collected at 100 K on an Agilent Technologies Supernova system using Cu Kα radiation with exposures of over 1.0°. X-ray data were treated using CrysAlisPro software. X-ray crystal structures were solved using SIR-97, and weighted full-matrix refinement on F 2 was carried out using SHELXL-97 or SHELXL-2014 running within the WinGX package.

X-ray Crystallography

X-ray data for 2, TPA-pytri⋅KOH, [Ru(TPA-pytri)(bpy)2](PF6)2, fac-[Re(TPA-pytri)(CO)3Br], and [Pt(TPA-pytri)(CCPh)2] were collected at 100 K on an Agilent Technologies Supernova system using Cu Kα radiation with exposures of over 1.0°. X-ray data were treated using CrysAlisPro  software. X-ray crystal structures were solved using SIR-97, and weighted full-matrix refinement on F 2 was carried out using SHELXL-97 or SHELXL-2014  running within the WinGX  package.

elements.content:
All non-hydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically. Hydrogen atoms were placed in calculated positions and refined using a riding model.

Data Refinement Details for TPA-pytri·KOH.

The structure was refined as a two-component twin using the TWIN and BASF commands. All non-hydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically. Hydrogen atoms attached to carbon atoms were placed in calculated positions and refined using a riding model. After considering the crystal packing of this structure, a hydrogen atom (H1A) of the hydroxide ion was placed in a calculated position and oriented in such a way that minimizes steric clashes between H1A and nearby hydrogen atoms (H3, H15, H18, and H19) from adjacent TPA-pytri molecules.

elements.content: All non-hydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically. Hydrogen atoms were placed in calculated positions and refined using a riding model. No satisfactory structural solution was obtained in the higher symmetry P21/n space group. The reported structure was obtained in the lower symmetry space group P1̅. It is worth mentioning that both Δ and λ isomers of the [Ru­(TPA-pytri)­(bpy)2]2+ cation molecules were found in the asymmetric unit.

Data Refinement Details for [Ru(TPA-pytri)(bpy)2](PF6)2.

All non-hydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically. Hydrogen atoms were placed in calculated positions and refined using a riding model. No satisfactory structural solution was obtained in the higher symmetry P21/n space group. The reported structure was obtained in the lower symmetry space group P1̅. It is worth mentioning that both Δ and λ isomers of the [Ru(TPA-pytri)(bpy)2]2+ cation molecules were found in the asymmetric unit.

The SIMU command was used to model some of the phenyl rings that were slightly disordered.

elements.content: Cyclic and differential-pulse voltammetric experiments in DMF were performed at 20 °C on solutions degassed with argon. A three-electrode cell was used with a Cypress Systems glassy carbon working electrode (1.4 mm diameter), a Ag/AgCl reference electrode, and a platinum wire auxiliary electrode. The solutions were approximately 1 mM electroactive material and 0.1 M (Bu4NPF6) as the supporting electrolyte. Voltammograms were recorded with a Powerlab/4sp computer-controlled potentiostat. Potentials are referenced to the reversible formal potential (taken as E° = 0.00 V) for the decamethylferrocenium/decamethylferrocene ([Fc*]+/0) process. Under the same conditions, E° calculated for the ferrocenium/ferrocene couple ([FcH]+/0) was 0.48 V.
elements.clean_text:
Electrochemistry

Cyclic and differential-pulse voltammetric experiments in DMF were performed at 20 °C on solutions degassed with argon. A three-electrode cell was used with a Cypress Systems glassy carbon working electrode (1.4 mm diameter), a Ag/AgCl reference electrode, and a platinum wire auxiliary electrode. The solutions were approximately 1 mM electroactive material and 0.1 M (Bu4NPF6) as the supporting electrolyte. Voltammograms were recorded with a Powerlab/4sp computer-controlled potentiostat. Potentials are referenced to the reversible formal potential (taken as E° = 0.00 V) for the decamethylferrocenium/decamethylferrocene ([Fc*]+/0) process. Under the same conditions, E° calculated for the ferrocenium/ferrocene couple ([FcH]+/0) was 0.48 V.

A mixture of 4-(5-bromopyridin-2-yl)-2-methylbut-3-yn-2-ol (402 mg, 1.67 mmol, 1 equiv), 4-(diphenylamino)­phenylboronic acid (968 mg, 3.35 mmol, 2 equiv), and catalyst [Pd­(1,1′-bis­(diphenylphosphino)­ferrocene)­Cl2]·CH2Cl2 (57 mg, 70 μmol, 0.04 equiv) in 1,2-dimethoxyethane (15 mL) was degassed with nitrogen gas for 25 min. Aqueous sodium carbonate solution (1 M, 3.3 mL, 2 equiv) and aqueous sodium hydroxide solution (3 M, 1.1 mL, 2 equiv) were added. The resulting solution was heated at 80 °C for 20 h, under a nitrogen atmosphere. The reaction mixture was extracted with CH2Cl2 (2 × 50 mL). The organic layers were combined, washed with aqueous 0.1 M ethylenediaminetetraacetic acid (EDTA)/NH4OH (2 × 50 mL), then water (2 × 50 mL), and brine (2 × 50 mL), and dried over Na2SO4, and the solvent was removed under reduced pressure. The crude product was purified by column chromatography (silica, CH2Cl2, and then 9:1 diethyl ether/petroleum ether). The solvent was removed under reduced pressure to give 1 as a yellow solid. Yield: 510 mg (75%). Anal. Calcd for C28H24N2O·0.5H2O: C, 81.33; H, 6.09; N, 6.77. Found: C, 81.03; H, 6.34; N, 6.45. 1H NMR (400 MHz, CDCl3): δ 8.79 (d, 4 J = 2.1 Hz, 1H, Ha), 7.88 (dd, 3 J = 8.1 Hz, 4 J = 2.1 Hz, 1H, Hb), 7.49 (d, 3 J = 8.1 Hz, 1H, Hc), 7.45 (d, 3 J = 8.7 Hz, 2H, He), 7.29 (td, 3 J = 7.5 Hz, 4J = 1.7 Hz, 4H, Hh), 7.11–7.17 (m, 6H, Hf, Hg), 7.08 (t, 3 J = 7.3 Hz, 2H, Hi), 1.66 (s, 6H, Hd). 13C NMR (100 MHz, CDCl3): δ 148.5, 147.7, 147.4, 140.7, 135.5, 133.9, 130.2, 129.5, 127.8, 127.1, 125.0, 123.6, 123.4, 94.8, 81.5, 65.6, 31.4. HRESI-MS (CH2Cl2). Calcd for C28H25N2O+: m/z 405.1961 ([1 + H]+). Found: m/z 405.1961. IR (ATR): ν 3032 (w, OH), 2921, 2112 (w, CC), 1587, 1486, 1274, 835, 754, 694, 518 cm–1.

4-(6-Ethynylpyridin-3-yl)-<italic>N</italic>,<italic>N</italic>-diphenylaniline (<bold>2</bold>)

Compound 1 (260 mg, 0.643 mmol, 1 equiv) was dissolved in toluene (25 mL). Crushed KOH powder (217 mg, 3.87 mmol, 6 equiv) was then added. The resulting mixture was stirred at 80 °C for 20 min. The unreacted KOH was filtered through Celite and washed with CH2Cl2 (2 × 10 mL). The filtrate was washed with water (3 × 50 mL) and then brine (3 × 50 mL). The organic layer was dried over Na2SO4, and the solvent was removed under reduced pressure. The product was passed through a plug of silica (eluent: 4:1 diethyl ether/petroleum ether). The solvent was removed under reduced pressure to give 2 as a yellow solid. Yield: 192 mg (86%). Anal. Calcd for C25H18N2: C, 86.68; H, 5.24; N, 8.09. Found: C, 86.17; H, 5.48; N, 7.79. 1H NMR (400 MHz, CDCl3): δ 8.81 (s, 1H, Ha), 7.82 (dd, 3 J = 8.1 Hz, 4J = 2.2 Hz, 1H, Hb), 7.52 (d, 3 J = 8.2 Hz, 1H, Hc), 7.45 (d, 3 J = 8.8 Hz, 2H, He), 7.26–7.32 (m, 4H, Hh), 7.11–7.17 (m, 6H, Hf, Hg), 7.07 (t, 3 J = 7.3 Hz, 2H, Hi), 3.19 (s, 1H, Hd). 13C NMR (100 MHz, CDCl3): δ 148.6, 147.9, 147.4, 140.0, 136.1, 134.0, 130.0, 129.6, 127.9, 127.6, 125.0, 123.7, 123.4, 82.7, 78.1. HRESI-MS (CH2Cl2). Calcd for C25H18N2Na+: m/z 369.1362 ([2 + Na]+). Found: m/z 369.1348. Calcd for C25H19N2 +: m/z 347.1543 ([2 + H]+). Found: m/z 347.1532. IR (ATR): ν 3284 (w, CCH), 3056, 3032, 1586, 1474, 1325, 1279, 826, 756, 696, 621 cm–1. Orange crystals of 2 suitable for X-ray crystallographic analysis were obtained by vapor diffusion of petroleum ether into a CH2Cl2 solution of 2.

4-[6-(1-Benzyl-1<italic>H</italic>-1,2,3-triazol-4-yl)­pyridin-3-yl]-<italic>N</italic>,<italic>N</italic>-diphenylaniline (TPA-pytri)

Degassed 4:1 DMF/H2O (20 mL) was added to a mixture of 2 (214 mg, 0.618 mmol, 1 equiv), NaN3 (48 mg, 0.74 mmol, 1.2 equiv), l-ascorbic acid (109 mg, 0.619 mmol, 1 equiv), Na2CO3 (66 mg, 0.62 mmol, 1 equiv), and CuSO4·5H2O (77 mg, 0.31 mmol, 0.5 equiv). The resulting suspension was stirred and degassed with nitrogen gas for 10 min. Benzyl bromide (116 mg, 0.678 mmol, 1.1 equiv) was added to the suspension, and the reaction mixture was heated at 65 °C for 21 h. The reaction mixture was cooled to room temperature. CH2Cl2 (100 mL) and then aqueous 0.1 M EDTA/NH4OH (50 mL) were added to the reaction mixture. The organic layer was washed with aqueous 0.1 M EDTA/NH4OH (50 mL), then water (3 × 100 mL), and brine (3 × 100 mL) and dried over Na2SO4, and the solvent was removed under reduced pressure. The crude product was purified by column chromatography (silica, CH2Cl2, and then 2:1 diethyl ether/petroleum ether). The solvent was removed under reduced pressure to give compound TPA-pytri as a yellow solid. Yield: 242 mg (82%). Anal. Calcd for C32H25N5: C, 80.14; H, 5.25; N, 14.60. Found: C, 79.81; H, 5.43; N, 14.77. 1H NMR (400 MHz, CDCl3): δ 8.75 (d, 4 J = 2.3 Hz, 1H, Ha), 8.21 (d, 3 J = 8.3 Hz, 1H, Hc), 8.05 (s, 1H, Hd), 7.94 (dd, 3 J = 8.3 Hz, 4 J = 2.3 Hz, 1H, Hb), 7.47 (d, 3 J = 8.6 Hz, 2H, Hi), 7.33–7.40 (m, 4H, Hf, Hg), 7.26–7.31 (m, 5H, Hh, Hl), 7.12–7.17 (m, 6H, Hj, Hk), 7.06 (t, 3 J = 7.3 Hz, 2H, Hm), 5.60 (s, 2H, He). 13C NMR (125 MHz, CDCl3): δ 148.8, 148.5, 148.2, 147.6, 147.4, 135.4, 134.7, 134.5, 131.0, 129.5, 129.3, 129.0, 128.5, 127.7, 124.9, 123.7, 123.5, 121.9, 120.3, 54.6. HRESI-MS (CHCl3). Calcd for C32H25N5Na+: m/z 502.2002 ([TPA-pytri + Na]+). Found: m/z 502.1984. IR (ATR): ν 3031, 2951, 1587, 1486, 1274, 824, 753, 695, 521 cm–1. Solid K2CO3 was added to deuterated chloroform. The supernatant was added to compound TPA-pytri and gave a yellow solution. Yellow crystals of TPA-pytri and KOH adducts (TPA-pytri·KOH) suitable for X-ray crystallographic analysis were obtained by vapor diffusion of petroleum ether into this yellow solution.

[Ru­(TPA-pytri)­(bpy)<sub>2</sub>]­(PF<sub>6</sub>)<sub>2</sub>·H<sub>2</sub>O

cis-[Ru­(bpy)2Cl2] (104 mg, 0.22 mmol, 1 equiv) and ligand TPA-pytri (10 mg, 0.22 mmol, 1 equiv) were dissolved in ethanol (15 mL). The resulting solution was degassed with argon for 10 min and then heated at 125 °C in a microwave (200 W) for 1 h. The resulting orange solution was cooled to room temperature. A saturated aqueous solution of NH4PF6 (20 mL) was added dropwise to the solution to afford the PF6 – salt as an orange precipitate. The precipitate was collected by filtration, washed with water, ethanol, and diethyl ether, and dried under vacuum. <italic>fac</italic>-[Re­(TPA-pytri)­(CO)<sub>3</sub>Br]
